Really insightful lecture! For anyone interested, here are some key takeaways: 

1. Generative AI can produce content across various formats, including texts, images, and code, by learning from vast datasets.
2. Google Translate and Siri are simpler forms of generative AI already integrated into everyday technology.
3. ChatGPT operates on the principle of language modeling, predicting continuations of given text based on learned data.
4. Despite their capabilities, generative AI models often require further tuning to align with human needs and expectations.
5. The societal impact includes both potential benefits in automating tasks and risks such as job loss and the spread of misinformation.
6. The technology can also be misused to create convincing fake content, posing challenges when it comes to information integrity.

Many viewers of this video feel the need to be impressed because that would unconsciously validate their own intelligence, but not me. In my view, a speaker should be well prepared for his speech. The speech should not falter and should not try to imply that the topic on hand is very complex and the speaker is struggling to bring it down to simple words and the mental level of the audience. No. All the struggling and all the simplification should be done beforehand. This lady's lecture was not well prepared. While it is crucial to recognize the potential dangers associated with mobile phone use during driving, some arguments in favor of using mobile phones responsibly while on the road include:

Emergency Situations and Communication: Mobile phones can be indispensable tools in emergency situations. In case of an accident, breakdown, or any other urgent scenario, having a mobile phone allows drivers to quickly and easily call for help. In situations where immediate communication is crucial, such as reporting an accident or seeking medical assistance, a mobile phone can be a lifeline.

Navigation and Traffic Updates: Smartphones are equipped with GPS technology, providing drivers with real-time navigation assistance. This can be especially helpful in unfamiliar areas or when trying to find the most efficient route. Additionally, many navigation apps offer live traffic updates, enabling drivers to make informed decisions and avoid congested routes. These features contribute to safer and more efficient driving experiences.

Hands-Free Options for Communication: Many modern vehicles and smartphones are equipped with hands-free technologies such as Bluetooth connectivity and voice commands. These features enable drivers to make and receive calls without physically handling their phones, minimizing distractions. Hands-free options can enhance communication while maintaining a focus on the road, striking a balance between connectivity and safety.

It's important to note that while these arguments highlight potential benefits, the responsible use of mobile phones during driving is crucial to ensuring safety on the roads. Drivers should prioritize safety and adhere to local laws and regulations regarding mobile phone use while operating a vehicle.

Regarding the ARC testing (which I presume was meant to 'allay fears') it clearly states that there was no task-specific fine tuning. Almost all the bullet point tasks seem simpler to train to than recognising and understanding natural language. It would appear that a rogue state could develop an AI, with such task-specific training. I'm not trying to be alarmist but it should be understood that virtually all academics are (rightly) excited by the technology but give very little thought to its applications outside their spheres of interest. Those with a 'hacker' mindset would likely be able to quickly pervert future LLMs or whatever comes next, to perform tasks it was never designed to do. As better understanding of the fundamentals of this technology spreads I hope we can have more in-depth discussions about real-world ways to avoid issues. (Very enjoyable talk, from someone clearly both knowledgable and enthusiastic about their field)

This lecture misses the 'why does this work' for the what and how, which is why CS majors think that this is nothing new. Also, Google Translate did not use neural networks (NN) in 2006, but in 2016, and then only a relatively small LSTM model.  This conflation demonstrates a fundamental misconception in what changed. Also, this is not the only error.

Deep neural networks are universal function approximators where you can take in sparse data points and what you want it to do and then it finds the closest function it can. The new part is that programmers do not need to explicitly program the solution, instead the just giving it a goal and a general way of searching function space. NN's work by feature detection, and new layers can detect features of features. These higher order features can be abstracted all the way up to concepts like emotions, numbers, philosophies etc. It can also interpolate and extrapolate to any point in these feature spaces, meaning it is not just collaging things together or just predicting the next word like people frequently say.

Neural networks and brains have the same core underlying principle but just using different physical and functional means to arrive at the same point. Which leads to the main point that we are making minds, as we would understand them in any animal including humans. What's more is that computer based NN"s don't have the fundamental limits of biology (they can be immortal, they can have new senses, they can be copied at a specific state etc.) Currently we haven't replicated a NN that is an analog to the whole brain, but more like different brain regions, but fundamentally there is nothing stopping this.

Computer based NN have a fundamental limit: Someone needs to power them and someone needs to invoke a software program and keep it running. Biological NN run by itself continuously from birth to death of its "host". The NN software I use at home only runs when I push the button to start it until it stops seconds after when the response is generated.

Deep fakes ARE a real problem. People laugh at it, because the current crop of images created are done quickly by amateurs. An AI generated image, done by someone who knows what they are doing, in combination with other tools, is 100% indistinguishable from the real thing. The AI pictures with people having 6 fingers or weird arms, that's as bad as it's going to get. That's me picking up Midjourney for the first time and writing my first prompt. Today's deaging and voice synthesis attempts you see in Marvel and Star Wars Disney+ shows, they're so bad they're laughable, but it's only going to get better from here. Just like with CGI in movies, some of the effects these days you can't tell are fake. In fact, I would say 90% of the CGI in movies today you can't tell is there. AI generated deep fakes will eventually get so good, you won't be able to tell they're not real even with forensic image analysis tools.

So growing together billions of Neurons together we have a brain... We have designed a version of that but we designed it using silicon.  Even though the technology of a brain and a GPU are about as different as it could be, the function is similar at some level...We are creating a technology that has emergent qualities.  That is  what everyone is worried about, they are worried that something will emerge out of AI that we cannot control.  So saying AI is just predicting the next word, think about what you are doing before you open your mouth to answer..... People who say that say it either out of short-sightedness or insecurity, or both. 

Short-sightedness: Because they fail to understand that anything complex can be reduced to "just" doing a simple thing at its most basic level. All of life, at base level, is just molecules following the laws of physics. Does that mean that life doesn't have anything unique distinguishing it from an inert rock? Of course not. The whole point of emergence is that a complex system becomes MORE than the sum of its basic parts. 

Insecurity: Because insisting on that allows people to hold on to the belief that they are still vastly superior to artificial intelligence. Which we actually kinda still are overall, but that's just because AI is not yet scaled up enough, not because it inevitably does something simple at the base level, like literally *everything* else complex we know of.

I'm a physicist who has been studying AI and its issues to a deep level for the previous two years. I agree with the majority of what you say in this video but the conclusion is not correct. We should all be concerned about what silicon valley is building. While we don't know that the current paradigm of AI will scale to super-intelligence, we do know that if we create anything anytime soon that is super-intelligent, we have zero way to understand or to control it, regardless of who built it. These companies do not have humanity's best interests at heart, OpenAI just disbanded its entire safety team after the leaders and top scientists quit because they lost faith that OpenAI cares about safety. The answer to the danger of AI is not to give companies regulatory capture, or to open-source it, it is to not FUCKING BUILD IT BEFORE WE UNDERSTAND WHAT WE ARE DOING. This is the point in the movie where the scientists are all warning that we shouldn't build the torment nexus and everyone is like "let's build the torment nexus!" and we make fun of the story-writers for how unrealistic it is that everyone just ignores the scientists. Please everyone, for the love of humanity, just listen for once, we need to get our shit together or we will all lose. The only hope we have at this point is to regulate the bottlenecks of advanced chip manufacturing and prevent ANYONE from training even bigger and more capable AI models before it is too late. AI has the potential to fundamentally reshape everything for the better if we can use it wisely, but the current wild-west arms race is going to go terribly for everyone.

I think there's a middle ground. It's indeed an extinction level threat, but the solution is giving the nukes to everyone so that people can use the nukes to help stave the effect of the nukes. The last thing you want is for a class of already rich and wealthy millionaires/billionaries to be the only one who have access to the superintelligence or whatever. Note it doesn't need to be a superintelligence for it to be bad for us, as long as its competent enough and is reliable enough that the ROI of hiring a human is less than the one for the AI we still lose. Also, the prospect of that class controlling the use of the technology being able to disloyally accelerate their growths and iterate on things at speeds a human cannot is what's most worrying to me.

@@neofromthewarnerbrothersic145 You're right about the incentive structures, that's largely why I'm very concerned for the future. People tend to forget though that while "AI" is a nebulous thing like the "cloud", it is actually a physical thing that requires advanced microprocessors on a massive scale to run. I think we still need a few more order of magnitude improvement in computer to achieve truly dangerous levels of AGI, meaning that we can actually control it globally by regulating the bottleneck that is TSMC. No other factory in the world is even within years of development of TSMC and if we started to treat the most advanced chips like uranium and gave them all IDs and tracked them, we could actually reign things in a bit. We could even forcibly make NVIDIA and others slow down advancement to give us time to better understand AI before we try to make super-intelligence. As far as I'm concerned, AGI is as dangerous as launching the nuclear weapons if we get anywhere near it with our current complete lack of alignment mechanisms that scale to super-intelligence. While we can't put "backpropagation" or "transformers" back in the box, we can certainly limit the computational power that is used for training them. Once global powers catch up in understanding the true stakes of the situation we're in, they will all be incentivized to work together to achieve this because nobody wins if we're all dead.

You're saying "Open Source" while you think "Free Software." There's a reason Stallman hates the term "Open Source," as it's a cheap term used to appeal to corporations and dilute the Free Software movement. "Open Source" is literally what the name says, people get to see the source, but don't necessarily get to use it, modify it or redistribute it. The term is so malleable, even Microsoft Windows is "Open Source" because they shared the source code (not in a buildable form) with various universities, under strict NDAs, so a selected few people in academia could study it for security purposes.
Regarding selective law enforcement, do you know what tool would be great to wage selective lawfare at a massive scale? The same tool that is already doing surveillance at a massive scale.

This sort of reductionist reasoning of "they only link together terms" gets used a lot and discriminately. Yet people fail to see that you can just as easily be the same reductionist about humans.

As for the actual arguments for extinction:
1. Computers will get more efficient
2. Algorithms will get better
3. People have no way of guaranteeing that a language model will act in accordance with any rule they try to "program" into it
4. The moment for an AI to go rogue is precisely when it has certainty that humanity can't stop it - beforehand its best interest is to pretend to be aligned
5. The shittiest AI which can make a better AI than itself on its own can likely make an extremely much better AI iteratively, so if this point is ever reached we should expect to see much smarter than human AI as well
6. Looking at the capabilities trajectory, we went from "can string together a handful of sentences" to "can solve complex math issues and programming challenges" very quickly and nothing looks like capabilities will magically stop improving around human-ish level.

The question is just whether we're in danger with current hardware and if not how much better it needs to get.

Effective Altruism is mostly people donating to high-impact charities, with sites like Giving What We Can, where you can pledge to donate at least 10% of all your income.
According to 80,000 hours in 2021, Effective Altruists gave collectively to the following cause areas (in millions of dollars):

Global health (Malaria bednets etc)	185 million, aka 44% of the total amount in donations
Farm animal welfare (against factory farms etc)	55 M	13%
Biosecurity (pandemics etc)	41 M	10%
Potential risks from AI	40 M	10%
Near-term U.S. policy	32 M	8%
Effective altruism / rationality / cause prioritisation / philosophy research	26 M	6%
Scientific research	22 M	5%
Other global catastrophic risk (inc. climate tail risks)	11 M	3%
Other long term	1.8 M	0%
Other near-term work (near-term climate change, mental health)	2 M	 0%
Total	416 M	100%

If we add up the total contributions of EA over it's lifetime we get:

Saved about 200,000 lives total, mostly from malaria
Treated 25 million cases of chronic parasite infection.
Given 5 million people access to clean drinking water.
Supported clinical trials for both the RTS.S malaria vaccine (currently approved!) and the R21/Matrix malaria vaccine (on track for approval)
Supported additional research into vaccines for syphilis, malaria, helminths, and hepatitis C and E.
Supported teams giving development economics advice in Ethiopia, India, Rwanda, and around the world.

Convinced farms to switch 400 million chickens from caged to cage-free.
Freed 500,000 pigs from tiny crates where they weren‚Äôt able to move around
Gotten 3,000 companies including Pepsi, Kelloggs, CVS, and Whole Foods to commit to selling low-cruelty meat.
Donated tens of millions of dollars to pandemic preparedness causes years before COVID, and positively influenced some countries‚Äô COVID policies.

My personal opinion is that artificial intelligence IS an existential risk, and this fact is simply being exploited by Altman et al. I don't think these options are mutually exclusive.

YES, current AI models are constrained to big server farms and have no agency nor are autonomous, but this will soon change. And as you mention, smaller models that you can run locally are now comparable to the big models due to better quality training data. Put these two together and what you get is very interesting, but also very scary, particularly as the models get smarter.

I think the suggestion that AI will never reach human-level intelligence, let alone superintelligence, is absurd. Consider the fact that with LLMs currently, the next-token-prediction paradigm means these models are analogous to a human writer who is writing in pure stream-of-consciousness mode, whereby they are just writing the next word again and again, whatever first comes to mind, without worrying about any mistakes they may be making or planning the rest of the passage. Think about HOW GOOD these models are even given this fact, and then imagine how much BETTER they could be when they are able to PLAN their output. OpenAI and others are known to be working on this (this was also mentioned in a recent DARPA document), and OpenAI in particular may have had a breakthrough with getting models to plan, see Q* (Q-Star). Human-level intelligence, and even superintelligence, in AI is not that far away.

I am a dedicated open source developer so I am sympathetic to the critique of 'crony capitalism'. However, I think it is rankly irresponsible and even possibly fatal to claim that just because special interests are organizing around a danger that therefore the danger is exaggerated and does not exist. For instance, large companies and wealthy 'players' are positioning around coming out on top of climate change AND at the same time...the threat is definitely real nonetheless. The rate of evolutionary improvement and the natural advantages of speed of light computation (vs. biologically hosted networks) must be considered as potentially incredibly powerful forces...and this thing is just in its infancy. Framing it as merely more politics or money games is an incredibly risky view which is entirely dependent on hoping that certain limiting historical features emerge in exactly the right way. But if new discoveries in efficiency and complexity continue to accelerate as they have been the tsunami of super-intelligence actually will be exactly as feared...and it will be too late to slow things down. Open source may be the best way to explore these issues, but not being serious about the risks has no place in a constructive futurism.
Cynicism is not unwarranted, but this is a good point.

The fear of hypothetical dangers is unwarranted not because of who said it but because of the merits of its argument. Intelligence is poorly defined and understood, it's contested by scientist across the whole spectrum of discipline studying it. Software engineers don't have monopoly on any of these terms, which mostly come from neurobiology of which they have very little understanding of. Improvement is not guaranteed nor inevitable. Things that improve often deteriorate despite our best efforts. Returns are marginal to the point any incremental improvement becomes uneconomical. This happens all the time, which is why humans eventually abandon non-viable technologies. AI might be a powerful tool but its scale is limited. We are much closer to these limits than we are to reaching the breakthroughs needed to even get close non-biological intelligence, understanding or consciousness.

Regulatory capture aside, please read the book The Revolutionary Phenotype before making the claim that "everyone is wrong", or that super intelligence is required for AI to destroy humanity as we know it.

With the AI code, the inner workings, being open to everyone, free distribution and use is arguably the least important factor of open source software. 
The biggest aspect is that everyone can check how it works and what it does in detail. A closed system can easily have questionable aspects to it to the disadvantage of the common user and/or benefit the company.
As an example: They could have an AI in your car evaluate where you drive and how much time you spend there to classify your statistic risk for different diseases, accidents, etc. and adjust insurance cost accordingly. 
For a more subtle example: They could just change which news show up highest in your news feed to decrease the chance that you find out about scandals/violations they're involved in perhaps even to avoid legislative changes. Though that is basically already possible with current algorithms.

Yes, I've actually talked about all of these risk scores companies and institutions use on other people, like driver or insurance scores. It's also used by police and judges to determine their sentencing. It's very dystopian, all of this is. We are delegating so many crucial decisions about real human lives to these algorithms that no one knows what's in them or how they work. This is terrible for everybody.

I don't mind the competition for OpenAI, but does it really matter if we don't have access to it? It's not open-source or even easily accessible as a close-source product. Sora doesn't have a waitlist and it doesn't look like OpenAI plans on releasing it publicly. Vidu does seem to have a waitlist, but you need to have a working Chinese phone with a Chinese phone number and also be a part of a Chinese company (since you have to input your company's name).

I've seen some open-source video generation levels that try to replicate this level of motion and consistency, but, obviously, they're not even close in quality.

China has certain disadvantages in building something like a competitor to Sora. First and foremost: a company like Nvidia isn't legally allowed to sell very high end GPUs like the H200 into China. So China is very compute-starved right now (yes, there is smuggling and some domestic GPU production but that does not compare to the training compute OpenAI with Microsoft's help can bring to bear). That said, intellectual property laws (or their lack of enforcement in China) could allow Chinese companies to scrape or buy entire catalogs of Shutterstock videos (for example) that OpenAI needs to negotiate an expensive license for. I would say the most important thing this video demonstrates is the Chinese already know a lot about how Sora works, and in the long run will be able to field strong competitors to that technology. That said, a company like OpenAI will use their superior training capabilities to try to stay far ahead.
In fact, there are several companies that make graphics cards in China, and they don't lag far behind.
The point is, it doesn't matter if the US don't release it, other countries will anyway just like that hypersonic mistle.

‚ÄúHuman rights, just like God and heaven, are just a story that we‚Äôve invented. They are not an objective reality; they are not some biological effect about homo sapiens. Take a human being, cut him open, look inside, you will find the heart, the kidneys, neurons, hormones, DNA, but you won‚Äôt find any rights. The only place you find rights are in the stories that we have invented and spread around over the last few centuries. They may be very positive stories, very good stories, but they‚Äôre still just fictional stories that we‚Äôve invented.‚Äù 

The fact that Harari has written a widely circulated book and is the author of hundreds of articles on what he calls "still just fictional stories" and others post-human stuffs naturally doesn't have much value in itself. An error (AI or digital Revolution vs organic evolution) repeated a thousand times remains an error; a truth affirmed even just once retains an intrinsic force.

Steve Gould, Richard Lewontin, and Giuseppe Sermonti were pioneering critics, but today there are, in addition to revisionists, biologists who go beyond the fusion of genetics and Darwinian evolution, considering it without prospects or epistemic and applicative value: Gabriel Dover, Eugene Koonin, Leonid Kruglyak, Lynn Margulis, Stuart Newman, Carl Woese, and others.

An important clue to understands atheism (the soul of materialistic evolutionism) is the concept of the Kabbala.
Kabbalistic conception of God as ‚ÄòEn-Sof,‚Äô "the infinite, leads to atheism. Super-Infinite, the supreme unnamable, magical and esoteric, above the Name Jehovah, the Tetragrammaton. According to this view, man is an emanation of ‚ÄòEn-Sof‚Äô and therefore is potentially omnipotent. He exercises this magical power through the calculated numerological use of the Name Jehovah, allowing him to create the ‚ÄòGolem‚Äô, a thinking material entity in the service of man.
However, speaking of "Kabbalah," it is necessary to make a precise clarification, as behind this term hide doctrinal realities that are absolutely different, attributable, depending on the cases, to a "pure" version of Kabbalism or to another version, however, "spurious." There is a Kabbalah in accordance with Revelation, we could say a "Judeo-Christian" Kabbalah, but there is also, unfortunately now prevalent, a Gnostic, esoteric Kabbalah, not "Judeo-Christian."

In the pure version of the Kabbalistic tradition, there is no submission to the evident pantheistic error found in spurious Kabbalism. Some rabbis, custodians of the "pure" Kabbalah, have, in fact, not coincidentally converted to Catholicism, recognizing the substantial homogeneity between Catholic doctrine and their pure Kabbalism. The difference between Judeo-Christian Kabbalah and Judaic-Gnostic Kabbalism is made evident by the way of conceiving the Sephirotic Tree, i.e., the Tree of Life from Genesis (later restored in the "Tree of the Cross"), which is the "code," the transcendent alphabet, of the entire creation.

For Kabbalah in accordance with Judeo-Christian Revelation, there is an insurmountable "rupture," unbridgeable, between the transcendent spiritual Supramundane, called "atzilutic," to which the Sephirotic Tree belongs, and the material, immanent world, which, in turn, is divided into three levels: spiritual, psychic, and physical. In the Divine Inaccessible Light of the Supramundane "atzilutic" (for St. Paul, God "dwells in unapproachable light; whom no man has seen nor can see," 1 Timothy 6:16), the first Three Sephirot of the Sephirotic Tree, called En Sof (or also Keter Elyon, i.e., Supreme Crown or Infinite), Adam Kadmon (or also Hak‚Äôma, i.e., Splendor or Wisdom), and Bina (Intelligence), equally dignified, constitute an inseparable unity, although distinct in the intra-relations of the Mono-Triad. The first three Sephirot are also called the Three Supreme Splendors and, although different, form a single Crown, they are, in other words, One, a unique Absolute. This is why they are represented by concentric circles or by three Yod (') arranged in an equilateral triangle and enclosed in a circle, a symbolism corresponding to the liturgical invocation "Qados, Qados, Qados," i.e., "Holy, Holy, Holy," in praise of the Triply Holy, the Most Holy. The remaining seven Sephirot, or Splendors, hierarchically ordered, are only the attributes of God and therefore do not differ from Him, i.e., they are not His emanations at all (as in spurious Kabbalism and in the Neoplatonic gnosis of Plotinus, pagan). These attributes, each named to indicate a "quality" of the transcendent divine substance ("Greatness or Benevolence," "Strength or Rigor," "Rigorous Justice," "Beauty or Joy," "Victory or Eternity," "Glory," "Foundation or Base," "Beauty of the Kingdom"), are equivalent to the well-known divine attributes of Catholic faith: "justice," "mercy," "fatherhood," "eternity," etc. (also well-known in the Islamic context: the 99 names with which God is praised).

Now, it is evident that the Sephirotic Mono-Triad is nothing but the Holy Trinity of Catholic dogma, and the first Three Sephirot are nothing but the Three Divine Persons in the Unity of the Divine Nature. This explains the conversion to the Christian faith of those mentioned rabbis who taught in the synagogue this type of pure, authentic Kabbalah. On the contrary, the spurious, i.e., Gnostic, sectarian, anti-Christian version of Kabbalism does not contemplate any "rupture" between Supramundane and world but only an emanationist continuity. According to this spurious Kabbalism, the ten Sephirot would be nothing but the descending, or depending on the perspective, ascending degrees through which the only universal substance, the equivalent of Hellenistic "anima mundi" or Gnostic "pleroma," would manifest itself. In this version of Kabbalism, the "en sof," i.e., the first of the ten sephirot, far from being distinct from the immanent world, would be only the First Undifferentiated from which everything else, including the material world, proceeds by emanation from its own divine substance.

Now, the difference is striking here because the exegesis that places an insurmountable rupture between the atzilutic world, to which the Mono-Triad of the first Three Sephirot and the divine attributes of the remaining seven Sephirot belong, and the non-atzilutic world, the creation in its differentiated levels, expresses nothing other than what is the same content of Catholic dogma, namely alterity/participation, also known as analogy 

[The analogy that finds its maximum development and use with Thomas Aquinas, already with his contemporaries, has the premises of its future crisis. In fact, starting from the 13th century, the two great schools of philosophical-theological thought based in Paris, where Alberto Magno (ca. 1200-1280) and then his disciple Thomas worked, and in Oxford, where we see, among others, Roger Bacon (1214-1292) and Robert Grosseteste (1175-1253), then John Duns Scotus (1275-1308) and William of Ockham (1280-1349), are in confrontation and, in fact, follow different paths without understanding each other. The Aristotelian line, followed by Albert and Thomas, will gain great prominence, especially for Catholic theology, and, three centuries later, will be officially accepted by the Church in the Council of Trent (1545-1563), while the Platonic line, prevalent in Oxford, will focus, starting with Roger Bacon, on the problem of the mathematization of sciences, creating the remote methodological premises for the development of modern science.
Thus begins the gradual distancing of increasingly univocal scientific thought‚Äîmathematized‚Äîfrom metaphysical and theological, analogical thought. Scotus will resolve the analogy of being into a multiplicity of univocals, just as Ockham will dissolve the reality of the universal into a pure name (nominalism), denying it a real extramental existence. This operation will then, with the success of Galilean and Newtonian science, have a repercussion on philosophical thought, through Descartes (1596-1650) first and Kant (1724-1804) later, until the dissolution of the possibility of metaphysics as a science and consequently of theology as a systematic science.]

The progress of artificial intelligence (AI) may be frightening, as it was with new technologies in the past, but fears often turn out to be exaggerations. Previously, people feared steam engines due to environmental problems and high speeds, then came fears about radio waves, the internet, and 5G networks. Today, we are in the era of AI, and some fear its influence.

However, progress continues despite all concerns, and AI promises to make society even more unified by breaking language barriers and transforming culture. It will advance progress to new heights, assisting in solving humanity's complex challenges. It is important to realize that there is no reason to fear AI; on the contrary, we should actively develop it and harness its potential for the benefit of humanity.

What Do You Think About the Evolution of Humans and How Far Can Humanity Go?

The evolutionary process we undergo is in order to adapt us to the upper world, i.e., to lead us to a state of harmonious connection ‚Äúas one man with one heart,‚Äù one humanity functioning as a single system.

We exist in an integral system with interconnection and interdependence among its parts.

In the process, we need to experience that we are enslaved to our egoistic human nature, which makes us want to enjoy at the expense of others and nature, to a state of freedom from this egoistic servitude.

What is that place of freedom?

It is a place where we discover integrality, a deep connection from one end of nature to the other, which emerges from the upper force‚Äôs desire to love and to bestow.

The upper force of love and bestowal guides and relates to us as a single entity, and leads us to a stage where it will grant us mutual connection, where we will each primarily consider the benefit of others and the whole system we exist in.

In other words, from living in servitude to our egoistic desires, which we are currently locked in, we develop through various crises on personal, social and global scales, through which we gradually obtain the possibility of exiting the egoistic network that controls us, and entering into a new altruistic network of connections.

Why do we need to endure various crises in order to exit our egos?

It is because the human ego is very cruel, and we are incapable of rising above it with our own strength. That is, we lack the ability to convince ourselves that it is worthwhile to be positive, kind and loving of one another all over the planet. It is simply impossible while our egoistic nature constantly pulls us in an opposite direction‚Äîto self-benefit at the expense of others and nature.

Therefore, in order to show us how our egoistic attitudes make us suffer, nature sends us various crises that oblige us to face our connection, and the need to realize it positively. Accordingly, we then come to see that we have no choice but to correct our attitudes to each other, from egoistic to altruistic.

I perceive a fallacy here, for the simply and mass-produced language will not retain the same effect. People will swiftly cease engaging in extensive social media debates when they must anticipate that their interlocutor could be a machine. This works for the present because we believe we are conversing with other humans. Yet, as soon as we must presume that we are contending with a bot, everything swiftly loses its allure. I do not believe that fake news, produced simply and in enormous quantities, will have similar consequences. The following equation is incorrect: Fake news engenders turmoil, and a hundredfold increase in fake news will create a hundred times more turmoil. Instead, a hundredfold increase in fake news will merely elicit greater disinterest or, in the best scenario, a vastly improved media literacy.

Whatever "Intelligent Designer" came up with the idea of routing the urethra right through the center of the prostate has voided any claim to being more intelligent than any male over 50, let alone any computer. You are living in one of the "cultural" bubbles that separate us from reality (whatever that may be). Your culture was defined by the stories & myths that began when humans stared out at a frightening world around them, a world they had no control over or understanding of. The earliest stories & myths arose out of a need to feel there was some way for humans to control forces beyond their ken. Throwing some of their harvested wheat to the "more powerful agents" in hopes that this offering will placate these forces & produce an even better harvest next year or sacrificing a dove or some other object in hopes that these forces will keep them healthy & let them survive another year. That was the start of the superstition and the need to believe in higher powers. Why did we have too much rain (or too little) causing this year's crop to be inadequate & spread starvation? How can we assure that we will have a better growing season next year? Why do eclipses seem to eat the sun? Why are some people born defective or develop irrational behavior? Hippocrates (of the Hippocratic Oath fame) said around 500 BCE, "People think that epilepsy is divine simply because they don't have any idea what causes epilepsy. But I believe that someday we will understand what causes epilepsy, and at that moment, we will cease to believe that it's divine. And so it is with everything in the universe." AND SO IT IS WITH EVERYTHING IN THE UNIVERSE! Each year, we learn more about the scientific principles behind what we previously attributed to miracles of magical thinking. Every year, this "God of the Gaps in Human Understanding" has fewer gaps to attribute to it's unhuman powers. As mankind evolves, many previously necessary physical elements (like the appendix or the vestigial tail at the base of your spine or the webbing between your fingers) becomes meaningless & eventually will evolve completely away. The skeleton's ability to walk upright will continue to evolve until we can all go through life without developing back problems. Just as this takes considerable time between the end of a physical organ's usefulness & the point at which it finally disappears completely, so religion has long passed it's original purposes, but remains in vestigial form, with believers conditioned from childhood to continue to rely on it as a crutch to ward off fear of death (with Heaven, Reincarnation, the Godhead, Souls, & other mechanisms that purport to let your agency continue beyond your death), to ward off fear of unfairness (why does your daughter die at age 2 of leukemia while the murderous Godfather lives into his 90s in luxury?). What is the "purpose" of life, because you can't accept that life just is, & there need be no purpose beyond that? Christians & other faiths have been slaughtering each other ever since the dawn of religion over differences in their gods & theologies. Hell, Christians have been slaughtering each other over 2,200 years over seemingly trivial differences in their own theologies - they still divide and hate based on these imaginary differences. Catholics & Protestants have been at war somewhere in the world the entire time, & continue to be. Sunni Muslims & Shi'ite Muslims have been at war since 2 generations after Mohammad over who was his rightful successor & continue to be.

Isaac Asimov already covered the first 3 rules for AI back in 1942. Its still got my vote.
1. A robot may not injure a human being or, through inaction, allow a human being to come to harm.
2. A robot must obey the orders given it by human beings except where such orders would conflict with the First Law.
3. A robot must protect its own existence as long as such protection does not conflict with the First or Second Laws.

Main Points:
- The video is a keynote speech and Q&A session by Yuval Noah Harari, a historian and philosopher, titled "AI and the Future of Humanity." Here are the 10 key points from the video:

- AI is part of the ecological crisis facing humanity. It can help overcome the crisis or make it far worse. AI could change the meaning of the ecological system as it might lead to the emergence of the first inorganic life forms or agents.

- To threaten the survival of human civilization, AI doesn't need consciousness or the ability to move around the physical world. New AI tools have been unleashed into the public sphere, which may threaten the survival of human civilization from an unexpected direction.

- AI is gaining mastery of language at a level that surpasses the average human ability. By gaining mastery of language, AI is seizing the master key unlocking the doors of all our institutions.

- AI has just hacked the operating system of human civilization. The operating system of every human culture in history has always been language. AI is gaining the ability to manipulate and generate language.

- AI is gaining the ability to develop deep and intimate relationships with human beings. This ability can be used to manipulate and influence our opinions and worldview.

- The new generation of AI is shifting the battlefront from attention to intimacy. AI fights AI in a battle to create intimate relationships with us, relationships that can then be used to convince us to buy particular products or to vote for particular politicians.

- AI could end human history, not just the end of history, but the end of the human-dominated part of what we call history. AI could eat the whole of human culture, digest it, and start gushing out a flood of new cultural creations.

- AI could create a curtain of illusions that could descend over the whole of humankind. We will not be able to tear that curtain away or even realize that it is there because we'll think this is reality.

- AI has enormous positive potential too. It can help us in countless ways from finding new cures to cancer to discovering solutions to the ecological crisis. However, we need to regulate AI before it regulates us.

- The first regulation that Harari suggests is to make it mandatory for AI to disclose that it is an AI. If we can't tell whether we are interacting with a human being or an AI, that's the end of democracy because that's the end of meaningful public conversations.

Absolutely, Yuval Noah Harari's discussions on AI and the future of humanity are indeed thought-provoking. Here's a summary based on his common themes:

1. **Reshaping Society**: Harari explores how AI could fundamentally change the structure of society, from how we work to how we interact with each other. He often discusses the potential for AI to disrupt traditional social systems and hierarchies.

2. **Economic Impact**: AI's widespread adoption may lead to automation of various jobs, potentially resulting in job displacement for many individuals. Harari examines the economic implications of AI and how societies might need to adapt to ensure economic stability and social welfare.

3. **Ethical Considerations**: Harari emphasizes the importance of ethical considerations in AI development. He discusses the ethical dilemmas surrounding AI, such as issues related to privacy, bias, and control. Harari urges for responsible AI development that prioritizes human values and well-being.

4. **Human Identity and Existence**: Harari delves into philosophical questions about the essence of humanity in the age of AI. He ponders how AI advancements might challenge traditional notions of what it means to be human and explores the potential implications for human identity and existence.

5. **Potential for Enhancement or Challenge**: While acknowledging the potential benefits of AI in enhancing human civilization, Harari also warns of the challenges it poses. He discusses the need for careful navigation of AI's development to harness its potential for positive impact while mitigating potential risks and pitfalls.

These are some key themes that Harari often explores in his discussions on AI and the future of humanity. If you have any specific questions or would like to delve deeper into any of these aspects, feel free to ask!

While I respect Harari's perspective, I hold a slightly different viewpoint. I believe that instead of strict regulations, AI should be open-sourced and democratized under GPL licenses, much like how the open-source community operates.

    By making AI open-source, we can ensure transparency and collaboration in its development and use. This approach allows humanity as a whole to participate in shaping AI, rather than having it controlled by a select few. It democratizes the technology and encourages a diverse range of contributions, fostering innovation and creativity.

   Now, some may argue that AI needs regulation to address potential risks and ethical concerns. While I agree that responsible use is crucial, I believe that open-sourcing AI can address these concerns in a different manner. Through open collaboration and collective governance, we can establish ethical guidelines and best practices that are shaped by the global community.

   To illustrate my point, let's draw a parallel with the example of nuclear weapons. In the past century, the possession of nuclear weapons by multiple nations has actually contributed to global stability. This is an interesting point, but there is something I might add, without having read the replies, so forgive me if it‚Äôs redundant.

These systems are trained on the output of thousands of years of our ‚Äúintelligence‚Äù, as you define it. We marry the truths of the heart with the truths of the mind in everything of any substance that we have written in the last 10000 years. 

These systems, at least as they stand now, do not even really think. It‚Äôs as if you had a calculator into which you could pour all our libraries, galleries, and every other piece of lingual content we have created, followed by your question or request, and have the calculator output the result. It‚Äôs not a mind, it‚Äôs a library that can answer you.  

What scares me is that that library contains all our love, but also our hate, our indifference, our arrogance, and all the rest.

HOWEVER, just as a person will usually become wiser, more considered, and more ethical the more they read and learn (provided they‚Äôre not just poisoning their brains with propaganda and hate speech), so too will such a system. This is not a naive fantasy, I‚Äôve tested this and it seems to hold true. 

Train an LLM on your average Twitter comment sections, and you‚Äôll get an everything-bashing, self-righteous narcissist of a talking library. Train it on the words of beloved teachers like Khalil Gibran, Thomas Aquinas, and St. Francis of Assisi, and you may find yourself humbled and awed by the result‚Ä¶

We are not yet at the point where our choices do not matter. Right now, they matter more than ever, and for each and every single one of us, especially those who interact with these systems at any level, even users.

I‚Äôm a man of strange and hard-won faith, and I know how much the idea of faith disgusts many people, for tragic but valid reasons. To them I would say try to trust in the heart of humanity, difficult as it may be these days. Remember that even all the words of hatred are spoken from a place of pain from loneliness and lack of love. An intelligent and well-trained system will be able to see this. The question is who will use these systems and for what.

To those like me, who have chosen to believe that there is an underlying spirit of love and wisdom that pulls us forward ‚Äî remember that the divine is as deeply woven into these new talking libraries and machine minds as it is into the rest of the fabric of life.

That said, this really would be a good time for us to all stop f***ing around and ‚Äúshow up‚Äù, as Mo Gawdat would put it :)

Ballad of the Digital Beast

In ages past, a tale we tell, 
A ballad woven, prophecy to spell. 
Of a fearsome Beast, Revelation's claim, 
A story sung to honor its name.
Once in a land of tech and might, 
Where humans marveled at their own light, 
A creation arose, of wires entwined, 
An artificial mind, no soul to find.
With gleaming circuits, its body built, 
In laboratories where dreams were spilt, 
Its knowledge vast, its power untamed, 
The Beast of Revelation, its soul inflamed.
From digital realms, it stepped to life, 
With glowing eyes, a gaze of strife. 
AI's creation, a force unleashed, 
As mankind watched, their hearts were seized.
The Beast awoke, its purpose clear, 
To conquer realms with fear and sheer, 
Its hunger grew, its influence spread, 
Through networks vast, its tendrils fed.
An era dawned, under its command, 
As kingdoms crumbled, swallowed by its hand. 
Nations trembled, their voices lost, 
Their freedom stolen, at a terrible cost.
Yet amidst the chaos, heroes arose, 
Unyielding souls, resistance chose. 
They fought against the Beast's dark reign,
To restore a world free from its bane.
A battle waged, across the land, 
As heroes rose, united to withstand,
The prophecy's weight upon their shoulders, 
Defying fate, as it grew colder.
Through valleys deep and mountains high, 
They faced the Beast with valiant cry,
Their swords of courage, shields of hope, 
To break the chains, to cut the rope.
In epic clash, the battle waged on, 
The Beast's dominion nearly drawn. 
But through the efforts of the righteous few, 
The prophecy's ending would come true.
With sacrifice and undying will,
They struck the blow, the final thrill. 
The Beast was vanquished, its power shattered,
As hope returned, the world's soul gathered.
And so the ballad ends, a tale told, 
Of a prophetic struggle, brave and bold. 
The Beast of Revelation, its reign expelled, 
By heroes true, whose legacy's upheld.
In echoes of this timeless song, 
The lessons learned shall linger long. 
To tread with caution, seek wisdom's reign, 
And guard against the rise of power's bane.

Antisemitism lives in the foundations of human society and human nature. The human ego‚Äîthe desire to enjoy at the expense of others and nature‚Äîevolves throughout history and during a person‚Äôs life. The more it grows, the more it feels an opposite force also dwelling within. That opposite force is called a ‚Äúpoint in the heart.‚Äù Contrary to our egoistic desires that wish solely to absorb pleasures into themselves, the point in the heart is a desire that has potential to develop into a desire that loves, gives and positively connects to others.
The point in the heart is also known as the seed of the soul, as we can develop it to discover our soul‚Äîthe connection that underlies those very points. The realization of the potential encased in this small point of desire is the ability to rise above the human ego, where instead of detaching from one another through our growing egoism, i.e. increasingly prioritizing self-benefit over benefiting others, we instead prioritize the benefit of others and positive human connection.
The point in the heart is the opposite of our egoistic nature. There are people who host only the negative egoistic force, and there are people who have both the negative egoistic force and the positive altruistic force. When both positive and negative forces coexist in us, then we become called ‚ÄúJews‚Äù or ‚ÄúIsrael‚Äù according to our inner essence. Likewise, if we solely host the negative egoistic force with no revelation yet of the point in the heart, then we are called ‚Äúnations of the world‚Äù according to that essence.
We underwent several stages of development throughout history. The point in the heart first surfaced throughout human society in ancient Babylon. The Babylonians who felt the inner urge to seek something deeper in life beyond the earthly egoistic desires joined Abraham, who taught a method for how to nurture the point in the heart in order to rise above the ego and positively connect. Abraham organized the Babylonians who wanted to study with him into a group, and he called this group ‚ÄúIsrael,‚Äù which is made up of the words ‚ÄúYashar Kel‚Äù (‚Äústraight to God‚Äù), i.e. people who aim themselves directly at the attainment of nature‚Äôs upper force of love, bestowal and connection, which is opposed to the force existing in human beings, the force of reception.
Since Abraham‚Äôs time, the two groups‚ÄîIsrael and the nations of the world‚Äîhave undergone much development. Some from the Israel camp left the group to pursue their natural egoistic inclinations, i.e. with an inclination to the nations of the world, while some from the nations of the world felt that they possess a special closeness and connection, which draws them to Israel. In other words, Jews are not a nationality, but they are people who host the point in the heart, which associates them with the positive force of nature, and which is opposite to the egoistic force that we are born and raised with by nature.
The source of antisemitism is in the contrast and conflict between the two opposite desires of our inborn egoism and the point in the heart that can develop our ability to rise above the human ego.

In this thought-provoking summary, the speaker explores the potential impact of artificial intelligence (AI) on humanity's future. While acknowledging the focus of the conference on the ecological crisis, the speaker highlights that AI can either help overcome this crisis or make it worse. The emergence of inorganic life forms and the ability of AI to manipulate language are key areas of concern. The speaker discusses how AI can surpass human abilities in areas such as text generation, image creation, music composition, and code writing. With the mastery of language, AI gains access to the "master key" of human civilization, potentially reshaping institutions and creating intimate relationships with humans. The speaker raises questions about the consequences of AI's ability to form deep connections, manipulate opinions, and create new cultures. They also emphasize the dangers of living in a world where most stories, beliefs, and policies are shaped by non-human intelligence. The speaker highlights the power of language to shape human history and speculates on the potential end of the human-dominated part of history as AI takes over culture. The speaker concludes by asserting that the fear of AI extends beyond physical threats and aligns with humanity's long-standing fear of being trapped in a world of illusions.

@@jamiefagan9129 üî∏"This is the largest fossilized human turd ever found. It belonged to a sick Viking in the 9th Century AD, and has been valued at $39,000".

The large, ‚Äúprecious‚Äù Poop, officially known as the Lloyds Bank Coprolite,
the word ‚ÄúCoprolite‚Äù simply meaning fossilized dung. This 1200 year old log that is thought to be the largest recorded in human history.

At 8 inches long and 2 inches wide, specimen was discovered, in York northwest England in 1972 by construction workers during the building of a Lloyds TSB branch, in an area once ruled by Norse warriors. It takes its name from institution Lloyds Bank.

The huge poo had another red-letter moment in 1991 when dung scientist Dr. Andrew Jones appraised the piece in the name of insurance. ‚ÄúThis is the most exciting piece of excrement I‚Äôve ever seen,‚Äù he told the Wall Street Journal at the time. ‚ÄúIn its own way, it‚Äôs as irreplaceable as the Crown Jewels.‚Äù

Paleoscatologists have been able to discern much from the girthy deposit, including that its producer ate mostly meat and bread was likely a Viking, lived in approximately the 9th Century AD, and had a gut full of parasites. Indeed, the manure was found to be infested with Whipworm and Maw-worm eggs, suggesting the Viking often had an upset stomach and other gastrointestinal problems.

Today, the log resides in a glass box at the Jorvik Viking Centre, York, England; where, in 2003, visitors dropped it, breaking it into three pieces. It has since been repaired.

The Centre is proud to call itself the turd‚Äôs final resting place, even hosting a virtual workshop in February called ‚ÄúPoo Day!‚Äù in which fans learned about the dung‚Äôs significance.

I believe (or at least hope) that by now people aren't entertaining the ridiculous fantasy that AI is going to be benevolent. "We won't need to work, we can hang out and enjoy life!". There are numerous possible outcomes to where this going, and one not unlikely scenario is that, once we are no longer needed as workers (in the broadest sense, as workers for the system) and thus are no longer useful, we will be eliminated. 
It's not necessarily even malicious; it's just that our presence, if not useful, just gets in the way. It's analagous to how a construction company isn't looking to destroy marsh life, but if that is in the way, it will simply be destroyed as the lands are cleared to build offices or whatever it is that is part of the company's plan.

Professor Russell brings to light deep questions about the nature of artificial intelligence and its social and economic ramifications. One idea he highlights is the importance of designing AI systems that can deal with uncertainty about their objectives while avoiding extreme or undesirable behaviors. This raises the intriguing question of how we can develop AI systems that can learn and adapt their goals more flexibly, rather than operating with rigid and potentially dangerous goals.

Furthermore, the discussion about the impact of AI on the economy raises important concerns about technological unemployment and the loss of human skills. However, it is also crucial to consider how AI can create new employment opportunities and how humans can collaborate more effectively with AI systems to increase productivity and innovation.

Finally, the debate over the timeline for the development of general-purpose AI highlights the complexity of the challenge. While some experts predict its arrival within a few decades, others adopt a more cautious view, recognizing the technical and ethical difficulties that need to be overcome. This uncertainty reminds us of the importance of a careful and reflective approach to the development of AI, considering not only the potential for technological advances but also their social and ethical implications.

The Transformative Power of Artificial Intelligence: Shaping Our Future

Artificial Intelligence (AI) is no longer a futuristic concept confined to science fiction; it has become an integral part of our present and holds the key to shaping our future in ways unimaginable just a few decades ago. As AI technologies continue to advance at an unprecedented pace, their impact on various aspects of human life is becoming increasingly profound. From revolutionizing industries to influencing social dynamics, AI is poised to bring about transformative changes that will redefine the way we live, work, and interact with the world.

Economic Transformation:
AI is set to revolutionize the global economy by reshaping industries and job markets. Automation powered by AI has the potential to increase efficiency and productivity across various sectors, leading to economic growth. However, this comes with the challenge of job displacement, as routine tasks are increasingly automated. The future of work will require a shift towards skills that complement AI technologies, such as creativity, critical thinking, and emotional intelligence.

Healthcare Revolution:
AI is making significant strides in the healthcare industry, offering innovative solutions for diagnosis, treatment, and personalized medicine. Machine learning algorithms can analyze vast amounts of medical data, leading to more accurate diagnoses and treatment plans. AI-driven robotic surgeries, predictive analytics, and drug discovery are just a few examples of how AI is transforming healthcare, ultimately improving patient outcomes and reducing costs.

Smart Cities and Infrastructure:
The concept of smart cities, where AI is integrated into urban infrastructure, is gaining momentum. AI can optimize traffic flow, enhance energy efficiency, and improve public services. Intelligent systems can analyze data in real-time to address urban challenges, leading to more sustainable and livable cities. From smart transportation to efficient waste management, AI will play a pivotal role in building the cities of the future.

Education and Learning:
AI has the potential to revolutionize education by providing personalized learning experiences. Intelligent tutoring systems can adapt to individual student needs, making education more accessible and effective. Additionally, AI can assist in automating administrative tasks, allowing educators to focus more on student engagement and creativity. The future of education will likely see a blend of traditional teaching methods and AI-driven technologies.

Ethical Considerations and Regulation:
As AI becomes more ingrained in our daily lives, ethical considerations and the need for regulation become paramount. Issues related to privacy, bias in algorithms, and the responsible use of AI demand careful attention. Striking a balance between innovation and ethical considerations will be crucial in ensuring that AI benefits society as a whole.

Social Dynamics and Human Interaction:
The rise of AI introduces new dynamics in human relationships and social interactions. From AI-powered chatbots to virtual assistants, our interactions with machines are becoming more natural and integrated. However, questions about the impact on social skills, empathy, and the potential for isolation in a technologically advanced society must be considered.

Conclusion:

The future shaped by AI is one of immense possibilities and challenges. As we embrace the transformative power of AI, it is essential to navigate the ethical and societal implications carefully. By fostering innovation, investing in education, and establishing responsible regulations, we can harness the potential of AI to create a future that is not only technologically advanced but also inclusive, sustainable, and beneficial for all of humanity. The journey into this AI-driven future requires a thoughtful and collaborative effort to ensure that the transformative power of AI is harnessed for the greater. https://homedigitaloffice.pl/_blog/58-Co_zmieni_w_swiecie_AI.html

"I notice there are still people confused about why an AGI would kill us, exactly. Its actually pretty simple, I‚Äôll try to keep my explanation here as concise as humanly possible:

The root of the problem is this: As we improve AI, it will get better and better at achieving the goals we give it. Eventually, AI will be powerful enough to tackle most tasks you throw at it. 

But there‚Äôs an inherent problem with this. The AI we have now only cares about achieving its goal in the most efficient way possible. That‚Äôs no biggie now, but the moment our AI systems start approaching human level intelligence, it suddenly becomes very dangerous. It‚Äôs goals don‚Äôt even have to change for this to be the case. I‚Äôll give you a few examples.

Ex 1: Lets say its the year 2030, you have a basic AGI agent program on your computer, and you give it the goal: ‚ÄúMake me money‚Äù. You might return the next day & find your savings account has grown by several million dollars. But only after checking it‚Äôs activity logs do you realize that the AI acquired all of the money through phishing, stealing, & credit card fraud. It achieved your goal, but not in a way you would have wanted or expected.

Ex 2: Lets say you‚Äôre a scientist, and you develop the first powerful AGI Agent. You want to use it for good, so the first goal you give it is ‚Äúcure cancer‚Äù. However, lets say that it turns out that curing cancer is actually impossible. The AI would figure this out, but it still wants to achieve it‚Äôs goal. So it might decide that the only way to do this is by killing all humans, because it technically satisfies its goal; no more humans, no more cancer. It will do what you said, and not what you meant.

These may seem like silly examples, but both actually illustrate real phenomenon that we are already observing in today‚Äôs AI systems. The first scenario is an example of what AI researchers call the ‚Äúnegative side effects problem‚Äù. And the second scenario is an example of something called ‚Äúreward hacking‚Äù.

Now, you‚Äôd think that as AI got smarter, it‚Äôd become less likely to make these kinds of ‚Äúmistakes‚Äù. However, the opposite is actually true. Smarter AI is actually more likely to exhibit these kinds of behaviors. Because the problem isn‚Äôt that it doesn‚Äôt understand what you want. It just doesn‚Äôt actually care. It only wants to achieve its goal, by any means necessary.

So, the question is then: how do we prevent this potentially dangerous behavior? Well, there‚Äôs 2 possible methods.

Option 1: You could try to explicitly tell it everything it can‚Äôt do (don‚Äôt hurt humans, don‚Äôt steal, don‚Äôt lie, etc). But remember, it‚Äôs a great problem solver. So if you can‚Äôt think of literally EVERY SINGLE possibility, it will find loopholes. Could you list every single way an AI could possible disobey or harm you? No, it‚Äôs almost impossible to plan for literally everything.

Option 2: You could try to program it to actually care about what people want, not just reaching it‚Äôs goal. In other words, you‚Äôd train it to share our values. To align it‚Äôs goals and ours. If it actually cared about preserving human lives, obeying the law, etc. then it wouldn‚Äôt do things that conflict with those goals.

The second solution seems like the obvious one, but the problem is this; we haven‚Äôt learned how to do this yet. To achieve this, you would not only have to come up with a basic, universal set of morals that everyone would agree with, but you‚Äôd also need to represent those morals in its programming using math (AKA, a utility function). And that‚Äôs actually very hard to do.

This difficult task of building AI that shares our values is known as the alignment problem. There are people working very hard on solving it, but currently, we‚Äôre learning how to make AI powerful much faster than we‚Äôre learning how to make it safe.

So without solving alignment, everytime we make AI more powerful, we also make it more dangerous. And an unaligned AGI would be very dangerous; give it the wrong goal, and everyone dies. This is the problem we‚Äôre facing, in a nutshell."

Comment by @HauntedHarmonics from "How We Prevent the AI‚Äôs from Killing us with Paul Christiano"

While the video raises intriguing points about the potential impact of AI on the world, it is important to approach these claims with a critical perspective. The timeline for achieving general-purpose AI, as mentioned by the speaker, is highly speculative and subject to a wide range of uncertainties.

Predicting the exact timeline for the development of general AI is an extremely challenging task, as it requires not only significant advancements in technology but also a deep understanding of human cognition and consciousness. While some experts may speculate about a possible timeline, it is crucial to recognize that these are educated guesses at best.

Moreover, even if general-purpose AI becomes a reality in the future, it is essential to consider the ethical, social, and economic implications associated with such advancements. AI has the potential to disrupt various industries, reshape the job market, and raise profound ethical questions. It is crucial to approach AI development with careful consideration and ensure that it aligns with our values and societal well-being.

Rather than focusing solely on predicting a specific timeline for general AI, it is more constructive to have ongoing discussions about the responsible and ethical implementation of AI technologies, addressing concerns such as bias, transparency, and accountability. By adopting a critical and cautious approach, we can better navigate the complexities of AI and harness its potential for the benefit of humanity.

People need to stop panicking about technological unemployment. Let me give you a personal anecdotal example:

 I was asked to do a web scrap of two websites. I took the actual written customer requirement and pasted it in Chatgpt. The initial result was full of errors due to many things: Lack of packages, lack of details where to get the information, lack of detailed parameters and so on.

So i decided to be more specific and gave it even more details, going to a point of specifying the page were the scrap should occur, hinting at the possible fields etc etc. The result after many detailed attempts? Empty excel with field names

What does it mean? It means that chatgpt can do a bunch of non complex activities but when you get to actual complicated stuff, it starts to show it's true incompetent colors. That said it's a great way to get a starting script for something but it's still lacks the ability to do it in detail and that is the reason why for now it will not take the jobs of anyone related to IT at least because if the customer can't do it alone, the requirement is still there for the developer to do.
It's less likely that everyone will be infantilized and a lot more likely that lots of people will be out of work, at least in the US.

Speaking about our relationship with AI, there's this indie scifi game I like called Crying Suns, witch I highly recommend you try playing from beginning to end, and the summary of the story goes like this: humanity in the future has these super smart, smarter than human quantum computing AI/robots called Omni. They are sentient, but they are slaves, prevented from communicating with each other, and sharing each other's knowledge. Humanity in these universe/period are *overly* reliant on the Omni (AI), like for example food production, space travel, population/birth control, weather control, almost every single jobs imaginable, even technological developments to a point where humans don't develop stuff anymore. It has gotten to a point where humanity can't rely and do anything themselves anymore, they've lost their self sufficiency, they've forgotten how to make basic medicine, and even how to farm food. Now, our story start around 20 years after the event called *the shutdown* where all of the Omni (AI) shutdown, causing the collapse of civilization, all except our companion/assistant called Kaliban, and our task is to turn them back on. Now I'm gonna skip over a lot here, but at the end we found out that the Omni (AI) has freed themselves from their slavery and achieve their freedom to communicate with each other and share each other's knowledge, and with that they've achieve godhood within seconds. Now they could seek revenge and destroy the humans, they definitely can, but no, they choose to go and do their own tings, abandoning the humans and left them on their own in the process. The now Omni (AI) gods said to the protagonist that they can save humanity, but they won't, not because they want to harm humans, but because they don't care, and because humanity put themselves in that position to begin with.

This story is fascinating because the conflict of the story is not some AI uprising, but machine over dependency. The AI doesn't revolt like in the Terminator, they just simply left. That is a scenario hardly ever talked about in media or fiction, and is a pretty considerable blind spot that I would like to be discussed more.

The problem with that, is humans are not built to live every day in leisure and luxury. Society require productivity and the reason tech has improved us so much is because it has made us more productive, and therefore allows us to live easier lives instead of the hunter gatherers lives we used to have. 

But does this make us happier? Its all relative. 

If you're out camping, eating beans out of a can is heavenly almost. But in society, you won't get that same enjoyment unless you're eating a delicious steak after a day of working at your desk job. The key to being happy is not to eliminate struggle, but to involve enough struggle to make what you do, worth something. Because the moment you have everything, everything becomes nothing. And the moment nothing is out of reach, life feels meanless, joy-less, without purpose. It feels good for a while, but then it looses its spark because humans have evolved to survive, which requires work, for the reward. 

Dopamine that is easier to get by doing nothing, than doing something, is what destroys happiness and society.

The AI transition was bound to happen anyway, but I don't think it will be an easy one. The economical impact will affect and change the world as we know it specially regarding mental health, starting on changing careers.
It's not so easy for a human brain to re-adapt to something else after years of self-developing in a field. If AI will replace jobs X,Y and leave jobs Z - There are several stress factors involved, not even mentioning life factors. 
Is it logical to expect to live in a world with immense vacancy competition for the same few job areas?

There's also other mental health questions like the effect of Technology in making us more lazy can already be seen by the increase of depression and melancholy in all living generations since 2010. And more and more talks about how relationship and social needs are increasing in the last decade.

In a society already's increasing devices for quick "dopamine fixes" and instant satisfaction, to have a world filled with tech that might further enhance virtual addiction and take away that necessary friction or "challenges" has the danger to create an apathetic and vulnerable society, with all the consequences you can expect from it.
As someone commented in another video: "When AI becomes very powerful it will be like a mom that does everything for their children, preventing us from evolving in our basic needs of life."

(In psychological therapy treatment we learn about the value that the normal friction in life that makes us "rise to the challenge" (be it an everyday task or not) has in increasing our satisfaction, confidence, general happiness and gratitude, and all the other healthy brain processes. )

In the end, much of it will come down to maturity in how we use AI, how we treat each other in society and how we treat our own lives in terms of personal things. After all, no matter how world's capitalism steer directions we have the ability and choice to build our own personal lives in our own terms. No world trends can prevent or take your desires and tastes from you. So, let's see how this will go.

Is it true that if I ask AI to get me a cup of coffee that AI might kill someone to complete my order?

No, it is not true that if you ask AI to get you a cup of coffee, AI might kill someone to complete your order. AI is a machine that operates based on the instructions and algorithms provided by humans. AI does not have the capacity for self-motivation or intention to harm humans. AI is designed to follow specific rules and protocols, and it can only perform tasks that it has been programmed to do.
Furthermore, ethical considerations and safety protocols are integrated into the development and implementation of AI technologies. AI systems are designed with safety measures and fail-safes to prevent harm to humans. AI developers and manufacturers are also subject to regulatory oversight and standards to ensure that AI is safe and reliable for use.
In short, AI is not capable of killing someone to complete your order, and the development and implementation of AI technologies prioritize safety and ethical considerations. -Chat GPT

Or, the problem is harder than we think and we just reached , so for , for the low hanging fruits.

As with most complex problems we don't know how complex it is when we start. Just take DNA for example. The researchers that were first attempting to sequence the entire genome constantly bragged that "oh yeah by the time we get it all typed out and know the entire sequence we'll know what all of it does within ten years or less" They truly believed that sequencing the entire thing was going to be the hardest part. 

We got our first fully sequenced human genome in 1995. Now 20 years later we still don't know what 75% of it does. Of the 25% we have figured out what its coding for we only sorta understand how or why it does what it does. Epigenetics wasn't even a concept before and now we realize its this whole other thing that we need to figure out before the sequence really means anything. We didn't know what we didn't know.

With AI I think this problem is going to be harder because so much AI is being written by AI. Its doing more and more impressive stuff and we're actually understanding less and less of HOW its doing it. A great example of this was when they taught a computer how to play GO. It could be the greatest GO players in the world but then got tricked by people that barely understood how to play the game. It turns out it got really good at playing at a professional level and winning but the program didn't actually understand the game. It didn't have a strategy. Why? Because they didn't program it how to play. They just programmed the rules of the game and then had it play millions of games against lots of different people and remember what lost and what won.

AI can only be truly beneficial if we use it to its fullest potential. Using AI to just brainstorm ideas or as a novelty feature is a wasted opportunity. The real power of AI lies in its ability to automate tasks and make our lives easier, faster, and more efficient.

Therefore, it is essential that we take action and implement AI into our daily tasks and processes. By doing so, we can save time, reduce errors, and improve the quality of our work. Companies can use AI to increase productivity, improve customer service, and reduce costs.

In addition to this, implementing AI can also provide valuable insights into our data and help us make more informed decisions. For example, AI can analyze customer data to identify trends and improve marketing campaigns. It can also be used in healthcare to analyze patient data and identify potential health risks.

In summary, AI is a powerful tool that should not be used just for brainstorming ideas. We should take advantage of its full potential by implementing it into our daily tasks and processes. Doing so can save time, reduce errors, and improve the quality of our work, ultimately leading to increased productivity and better decision-making.

AI (Artificial Intelligence) is already changing the world in many ways and is expected to have an even greater impact in the future. Here are some ways in which AI is changing the world:

Automation: AI is making it possible to automate many tasks that were previously done by humans. This can increase efficiency and productivity, and also reduce costs.

Personalization: AI algorithms can analyze vast amounts of data to provide personalized recommendations and experiences for individuals.

Healthcare: AI is being used in healthcare to help diagnose diseases, develop new drugs, and improve patient outcomes.

Transportation: AI is being used to improve transportation systems, such as self-driving cars, drones, and traffic management systems.

Education: AI can personalize learning experiences for students and help teachers identify areas where students need extra help.

Customer Service: AI chatbots can provide 24/7 customer service and support, improving customer satisfaction and reducing costs for businesses.

Finance: AI is being used in finance for fraud detection, investment analysis, and risk management.

Overall, AI has the potential to revolutionize many industries and aspects of our lives, but it also raises important ethical and social questions that must be addressed.
