@@marc1190 Thanks Marc! Well, a few days ago I enrolled in a Harvard cerificate online program for Intro to Python....Burnt about 10+ hrs on it, all seemed fine, got to my 1st lab exercise and completely failed, i unenrolled. At least I'll get a refund. I'm just dumber than a rock. Oh well.

Learning by just doing "monkey see, monkey do" is hard and I certainly can't do it. I often take multiple breaks and apply the Feynman method between learning sessions (Should be first thing to pop up if you google it).

When you have followed a piece of video and you've gathered some new information, then try to apply it. Don't be afraid of breaking anything, you can always reload the whole thing. "What happens if I change this 10 to 100? What happens if I call this method instead of that method". I find this to really solidify the idea in my head what these things actually do instead of plowing towards the conclusion the video has in store.

I also take notes. Lots and lots of notes during lectures. Instead of just watching how the lecturer imports some library, I insist on knowing what the general purpose of that library is. Also, gather extra information by just writing it in google. It really changes a line of code to something bigger and more easily understandable.

Instead of following a line of code like "import torch", check from google what that means. There's often documentations available on internet about languages and their libraries (of varying quality, torch documentation is great).

The flood of information is ridiculous at first, it's like trying to drink from fire post, but you don't have to read and know everything about everything right away, It's well enough that you understand the broad idea of something you are using and what it's useful for. For instance, you don't have to know everything about cars, it's enough that you know what they are useful for. If you have to modify or alter the car in some way, then it's perhaps better to gain more knowledge on the subject.

Programming is a fun hobby and when you finally finish your own project, no matter how small or stupid it is, it's magnificient sensation.

@@cacogenicistyes, but the point op is making is that all that data is meaningless unless a human gives it meaning: has done something with it/created a pattern AI can apply. 

The data AI is currently working with is highly semantic internet data, resulting from very specific human behaviour and therefore most valuable in its use, as it reflects patterns (meaning). As the video states, we are now looking at the less valuable data like pizza production errors where not enough concrete human input exists/is hard to manufacture and so coding for it does not make much commercial sense. 

AI has no inherent ability to develop patterns in data, it just aggregates existing human patterns at scale. When we are talking about AGI and emergence, what we are really looking for is some kind of pattern hidden in human behaviour/analysis and is reflected in the data, which has previously not been noticed.

I think most people solve trivial tasks with AI and think that means anything about real engineers.  A programming language is a deterministic way to express a solution to a problem. Why you would want to replace it with something fundamentally not context free makes no sense. You have two options - write the code as your understand it and then test/profile/optimize. Or automate the easiest part of software development (coding) by prompting it and hoping it produces the right answer - and then try to test/profile/optimize a system you don't understand.

Programming is NOT about telling a machine what to do - that problem has long been solved by compilers. Programming is about expressing a solution to a problem in a deterministic way. Text is simply the easiest way to express logic and unless you want to have no idea what your system does - it will never go away.

There is this false perception that programming is about writing instructions - and therefore an AI allows you to translate a human level language to machine instructions. No. Programming is about problem solving and the issue of translating human level logic to machine code (compiler) was already solved by people far smarter than you 3 decades ago.

All these opinions about AI replacing software engineers are about people who don't work in this industry or think web development/scripting counts as software engineering (it doesn't).

@@josephp.3341 I disagree. If there‚Äôs anything about problem solving it has to be mathematics and the mathematical algorithms involved in solving said problems. Programming is simply translating those mathematical steps or algorithms and implementing them onto a machine. @@hikemalliday6007 the VAST majority of Senior developers do not think AI is going to take all the jobs any time soon. It is really only Junior devs that think this is the case.

Which, if you think about it, makes sense. A Junior dev doesn't know much yet and been in the thick of it in development. They get handed tasks like "there is a bug on this page that moves the comment box out of alignment on mobile devices‚Äîre-center it on mobile devices without affecting desktop viewing." And that sort of bug is something that can be done pretty slowly by a Junior, possibly fairly quickly by AI, and super fast by a Senior dev.

But what people forget is that a Senior dev can't be bothered to realign a comment box on mobile devices. An office drone wouldn't know how to take ChatGPT's output and put it into the test environment without themselves becoming a Junior dev (though without any programming knowledge). So either the Senior dev has to now do the task, or they're going to need to train the office drone to the competency of a Junior dev who doesn't know how to program anything themselves.

The point of a Junior dev is to push that task to them. The Senior dev is trying to figure out how to stop the database from crashing when the user numbers spike 200% at intermittent intervals throughout the day, without needing to run the server at maximum all day long that would cost the company $20k/month.

Those tasks that get pushed to the Junior is how they become a Senior, so they can replace the current Senior and solve those $20k/month challenges. And the Senior dev needs to be replaced so they can move on to Architect or Tech Lead and identify changes to save $35k/month.

There is a huge shortage of Seniors right now, and the Seniors see absolutely no reason to believe AI is going to take their jobs. Eventually, companies will have to settle and hire more Juniors again. The companies who tried to replace 2 juniors with 1 junior and ChatGPT are going to find themselves in hot water when they need 2 Seniors and only have 1 Junior to promote.

@@TravisMedia agreed. As a bonus, JS has a lot of similar syntax and quirks to C/C++, so it can also be easier to pick that up (if you were so inclined).

And there are plenty of AI frameworks in JS that are similar to Python, so one can always start with JS and still do AI. As a bonus, you've already got a headstart on building out a web app to showcase your AI projects if you go JS. So if AI isn't your thing, web dev is right there, too. And you can try to work as web dev while studying AI.

Some JS library equivalents to Python (Python option ---> JS option):

NumPy ---> NumJs‚Äî(not all features, but most anything someone who isn't advanced would need‚Äîcan run in both NodeJS & the browser though, so a little easier to share online)

NumPy ---> Numpy.js‚Äî(a NumPy-lite version, very basic functions)

Matplotlib ---> mpld3‚Äî(tries to make matplotlib WITH d3.js functionality, some say it's better)

SciKit-learn ---> scikit.js‚Äî(pretty close to the same thing, differences are syntax mostly)

Tensorflow ---> Tensorflow.js‚Äî(as usual, not quite the same, but dang close!)
